title: Can the NBA Move On From This China Mess?
text:
This was supposed to be the Camelot NBA season. A league already touted for its compelling story lines, best-in-class progressivism, and support for individual expression had also seemed to achieve something like the grail of competitive parity. A series of off-season maneuvers among the highest tier of players had left the league more open than in recent memory; no longer would the Golden State Warriors start the season as presumptive champions.

Then, over the weekend, Houston Rockets general manager Daryl Morey tweet-and-deleted. The post was just an image that said, “fight for freedom stand with Hong Kong,” and it wasn’t up long, but it launched a continuing news cycle about the NBA’s interests and political bent. The league would likely have preferred to focus on Zion Williamson’s first preseason dunks, or even on how Kevin Durant told Hot 97 that the Knicks are no longer a cool team. But Hong Kong’s pro-democracy protests sat uneasily with an organization with massive strategic interests in growing the sport in China.

In its initial statement on Sunday, the NBA essentially asked Morey to get in line. “We recognize that the views expressed by Houston Rockets General Manager Daryl Morey have deeply offended many of our friends and fans in China, which is regrettable,” spokesman Mike Bass said. “While Daryl has made it clear that his tweet does not represent the Rockets or the NBA, the values of the league support individuals’ educating themselves and sharing their views on matters important to them.”

From there, well, everyone else joined in. “The only thing the NBA should be apologizing for is their blatant prioritization of profits over human rights,” Beto O’Rourke tweeted. “What an embarrassment.” “The brave #BlueCheckBrigade has trouble distinguishing between what is inappropriate & what is dangerous,” Marco Rubio wrote. “POTUS asking #China to investigate Biden is wrong, but it isn’t going to happen. China regulating speech in America is dangerous & is actually happening via @NBA.” Josh Hawley, Ben Sasse, Julián Castro, and Ted Cruz were among the other political participants landing in about the same place. Bari Weiss and the Washington Post editorial board too.

The breadth of that chorus brought into focus just how closely the league’s public face is tied with its politics, however accurately. As a matter of precedent, the NBA is widely expected to take these sorts of opportunities to support free expression. But the tone among the Rockets was more cautious. The NBA was the first major American sports league to play in China, and the Chinese streaming platform Tencent has said that 500 million in the country watched NBA programming last season. The Rockets in particular have had an outsize presence in China ever since the team drafted Yao Ming in 2002.

Morey himself didn’t explicitly apologize, but he walked his sentiment back. “I did not intend my tweet to cause any offense to Rockets fans and friends of mine in China,” he tweeted. “I was merely voicing one thought, based on one interpretation, of one complicated event. I have had a lot of opportunity since that tweet to hear and consider other perspectives.”

Rockets owner Timan Fertitta later told ESPN, “We got a huge backlash, and I wanted to make clear that the organization has no political position. We’re here to play basketball and not to offend anybody.” Standing next to his fellow Rockets star Russell Westbrook after a practice in Tokyo on Monday, James Harden went so far as to apologize to Chinese fans: “We apologize. You know, we love China. We love playing there,” Harden told reporters. “For both of us individually, we go there once or twice a year. They show us the most important love.”
description: The NBA had a better reputation than any other professional American sports league—but one tweet, and a subsequent diplomatic freak-out, may have changed all that, weeks before the season even begins.
